content:
Land molluscs are my main group of expertise. I use them as models in dispersal ecology, to study the causes and consequences of individual behaviour differences (or ‚Äúpersonalities‚Äù) and to understand the impacts of urbanization.
I work mostly with the common land snails Cornu aspersum and Cepaea nemoralis, but have handled 20 other species of land molluscs in the lab.

content:
I study orb weavers (primarily Araneidae, but also Tetragnathidae), as their webs are great integrators of their foraging strategies in response to environmental changes.
I also use money spiders (fam. Linyphiidae, especially Erigone sp.) as models to study the evolution of dispersal and integrated phenotypes.

content:
‚ÄúHe wondered whether home was a thing that happened to a place after a while, or if it was something that you found in the end, if you simply walked and waited and willed it long enough.‚Äù
Neil Gaiman, American Gods
Dispersal is one of the main mechanisms shaping evolution and genetic diversity (along with selection, recombination, drift and mutation) and one of three fundamental drivers of population dynamics (along with reproduction and mortality). Knowledge of dispersal is crucial to understand how/whether organisms will be able to cope, with current environmental changes, which are often spatially structured (such as habitat fragmentation).
I develop lab- and field-based experiments to understand how the interaction of various selective pressures shape the evolution of dispersal strategies and the association of dispersal with other traits in syndromes. I am also interested in unraveling the ecological and evolutionary consequences of such syndromes, especially in the context of human-induced rapid environmental changes and range expansions.
Main collaborations: Armelle Ansart, Julien P√©tillon, David Renault (University of Rennes 1), Sol√®ne Croci (CNRS, Rennes), Dries Bonte (Ghent University), Elodie Vercken (INRA, Sophia-Antipolis)
Collaboration networks: Member of the dispNet research network
title: Dispersal ecology and evolution

content:
"The unwritten rule among biologists is that, when prompted, one should answer gruffly that cities are only necessary evils where a true biologist spends as little time as possible. The real world lies outside the urban realm, in forests, dales, and fields. Where the wild things are.
But if I am honest I must admit I secretly like cities."
Menno Schilthuizen, Darwin comes to town, Quercus, 2018
Over half of humanity now lives in cities, and this proportion, along with the surface of urban lands, is expected to rise continuously during this century. Urbanization is one of the most dramatic and complex land use changes caused by humans, combining at various scales habitat fragmentation and loss, increased temperatures as well as light, noise and chemical pollution.
Many species are unable to adapt: urbanization has caused numerous population declines and local species extinctions, and is a major source of biological homogenization worldwide. This is likely in turn to influence human well-being and health, through the loss or degradation of key ecosystem services in cities. Yet, some organisms persist or even thrive in cities, directly or following evolutionary changes.
Using cities in France and Belgium, I investigate how various behaviours and life-history traits respond to urbanisation at various scales, and try to find out whether this affects population/ species persistence in cities and interactions with other species, including humans.
Main collaborations: Dries Bonte (Ghent University), Sol√®ne Croci (CNRS, Rennes)
Collaboration networks: Participant to the SPEEDY project; member of the Global Urban Evolution consortium (GLUE)
I also contribute to the Life in the City: Urban Evolution blog (edited by Elizabeth Carlen, Lindsay Miles & Kristin Winchell)
title: Urban ecology
